notes_translated.fr: La série de cartes de référence de 1961 à 2010 de l’Atlas du Canada contient une carte bilingue du Canada. Il s’agit d’une mise à jour de l’édition 2000 de la carte MCR 100. La principale modification sur la carte de 2004 est le changement du nom de Terre-Neuve pour celui de Terre-Neuve-et-Labrador (changement apporté en 2001). Les limites provinciales et territoriales sont indiquées, ainsi que la zone extracôtière de 200 milles marins du Canada. Les lieux habités sont représentés en six classes, alors que les routes sont regroupées en trois classes (autoroutes, routes principales et autres routes). La carte représente les voies ferrées et les trajets des traversiers, tous les parcs nationaux et tous les sites du patrimoine mondial au Canada. Des isobathes sont utilisées dans toutes les étendues d’eau salée. Puisque la carte ne comporte aucun carton des régions urbaines, elle offre une couverture beaucoup plus étendue des États-Unis. Les données datent principalement de 2000-2004, et celles pour les lieux habités proviennent du Recensement de 2001.
notes_translated.en: Contained within the Atlas of Canada's Reference Map Series, 1961 to 2010, is a bilingual map of Canada. This map is an update of the 2000 Edition of MCR 100. The main change included in the 2004 map is the change of Newfoundland's name to Newfoundland and Labrador (which occurred in 2001). This map shows provincial and territorial boundaries. Also shown is Canada's 200 mile offshore limit. Populated places are classified in six size categories. Roads are grouped into three categories (expressways, major roads and other roads). Railways and ferry routes are also shown. The map shows all of Canada's national parks, and all of Canada's World Heritage sites. Bathymetric contours are used for all saltwater areas. Because this map does not have urban insets, a much larger coverage area is given for the United States. Data is mainly as of 2000-2004, with the 2001 Census being used as the data source for populated places.

The main change included in the 2004 map is the change of Newfoundland's name to Newfoundland and Labrador (which occurred in 2001). This map shows provincial and territorial boundaries. Also shown is Canada's 200 mile offshore limit. Populated places are classified in six size categories. Roads are grouped into three categories (expressways, major roads and other roads). Railways and ferry routes are also shown. The map shows all of Canada's national parks, and all of Canada's World Heritage sites. Bathymetric contours are used for all saltwater areas. Because this map does not have urban insets, a much larger coverage area is given for the United States. Data is mainly as of 2000-2004, with the 2001 Census being used as the data source for populated places.
